001package squidpony;
002
003import regexodus.*;
004import squidpony.squidmath.*;
005
006import java.io.Serializable;
007import java.util.ArrayList;
008import java.util.Collection;
009import java.util.Iterator;
010import java.util.Map;
011
012import static squidpony.Maker.makeList;
013import static squidpony.Maker.makeOM;
014
015/**
016 * A text processing class that can swap out occurrences of words and replace them with their synonyms.
017 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 5/23/2016.
018 */
019public class Thesaurus implements Serializable{
020    private static final long serialVersionUID = 3387639905758074640L;
021    protected static final Pattern wordMatch = Pattern.compile("([\\pL`]+|@)"),
022            similarFinder = Pattern.compile(".*?\\b(\\w\\w\\w\\w).*?{\\@1}.*$", "ui");
023    public OrderedMap<CharSequence, GapShuffler<String>> mappings;
024    public ArrayList<FakeLanguageGen.Alteration> alterations = new ArrayList<>(4);
025    public SilkRNG rng;
026    protected GapShuffler<String> plantTermShuffler, fruitTermShuffler, nutTermShuffler, flowerTermShuffler,
027            potionTermShuffler;
028    public FakeLanguageGen defaultLanguage = FakeLanguageGen.SIMPLISH;
029    public transient ArrayList<FakeLanguageGen> randomLanguages = new ArrayList<>(2);
030    public transient String latestGenerated = "Nationia";
031    /**
032     * Constructs a new Thesaurus with an unseeded RNG used to shuffle word order.
033     */
034    public Thesaurus()
035    {
036        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
037        rng = new SilkRNG();
038        addKnownCategories();
039    }
040
041    /**
042     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with the next long from the given RNG.
043     * @param rng an RNG that will only be used to get one long (for seeding this class' RNG)
044     */
045    public Thesaurus(IRNG rng)
046    {
047        this(rng.nextLong());
048    }
049
050    /**
051     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with shuffleSeed.
052     * @param shuffleSeed a long for seeding this class' RNG
053     */
054    public Thesaurus(long shuffleSeed)
055    {
056        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
057        this.rng = new SilkRNG(shuffleSeed);
058        addKnownCategories();
059    }
060
061
062    /**
063     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with shuffleSeed.
064     * @param shuffleSeed a String for seeding this class' RNG
065     */
066    public Thesaurus(String shuffleSeed)
067    {
068        this(CrossHash.hash64(shuffleSeed));
069    }
070
071    /**
072     * Changes the sequences for all groups of synonyms this can produce, effectively turning this Thesaurus into a
073     * different version that knows all the same synonyms and categories but will produce different results.
074     * @param state any long; will be given to {@link SilkRNG#setState(long)}
075     */
076    public void refresh(long state)
077    {
078        refresh((int)(state & 0xFFFFFFFFL), (int)(state >>> 32));
079    }
080
081    /**
082     * Changes the sequences for all groups of synonyms this can produce, effectively turning this Thesaurus into a
083     * different version that knows all the same synonyms and categories but will produce different results.
084     * @param stateA any int; the first part of the state of a {@link SilkRNG}
085     * @param stateB any int; the second part of the state of a {@link SilkRNG}
086     */
087    public void refresh(int stateA, int stateB)
088    {
089        this.rng.setState(stateA, stateB);
090        final int sz = mappings.size();
091        for (int i = 0; i < sz; i++) {
092            mappings.getAt(i).setRNG(rng, true);
093        }
094    }
095
096    public Thesaurus addReplacement(CharSequence before, String after)
097    {
098        mappings.put(before, new GapShuffler<>(after));
099        return this;
100    }
101
102    /**
103     * Allows this Thesaurus to replace a specific keyword, typically containing multiple backtick characters
104     * ({@code `}) so it can't be confused with a "real word," with one of the words in synonyms (chosen in shuffled
105     * order). The backtick is the only punctuation character that this class' word matcher considers part of a word,
106     * both for this reason and because it is rarely used in English text.
107     * @param keyword a word (typically containing backticks, {@code `}) that will be replaced by a word from synonyms
108     * @param synonyms a Collection of lower-case Strings with similar meaning and the same part of speech
109     * @return this for chaining
110     */
111    public Thesaurus addCategory(String keyword, Collection<String> synonyms)
112    {
113        if(synonyms.isEmpty())
114            return this;
115        GapShuffler<String> shuffler = new GapShuffler<>(synonyms, rng, true);
116        mappings.put(keyword, shuffler);
117        return this;
118    }
119
120    /**
121     * Adds several pre-made categories to this Thesaurus' known categories, but won't cause it to try to replace normal
122     * words with synonyms (only categories, which contain backticks in the name). The keywords this currently knows,
123     * and the words it will replace those keywords with, are:

201     *     <li>flavor`noun` : acid, grease, herb, salt, smoke, spice, sugar</li>
202     *     <li>flavor`adj` : bitter, salty, savory, smoky, sour, spicy, sweet</li>
203     *     <li>color`adj` : black, blue, brown, gray, green, orange, red, violet, white, yellow</li>
204     *     <li>shape`adj` : delicate, drooping, fibrous, fragile, giant, hardy, hollow, long, miniature, spiny, stiff, stubby, sturdy, thorny, tufted, yielding</li>

211     *     <li>smart`adj` : aware, brilliant, clever, cunning, genius, mindful, smart, wise</li>
212     *     <li>smart`noun` : acumen, awareness, cunning, genius, knowledge, mindfulness, smarts, wisdom</li>

214     *     <li>stupid`noun` : carelessness, complacency, foolishness, idiocy, recklessness, sloppiness, stupidity</li>
215     *     <li>bandit`noun` : bandit, brigand, highwayman, pirate, raider, rogue, thief</li>
216     *     <li>bandit`nouns` : bandits, brigands, highwaymen, pirates, raiders, rogues, thieves</li>
217     *     <li>soldier`noun` : combatant, fighter, mercenary, soldier, trooper, warrior</li>
218     *     <li>soldier`nouns` : combatants, fighters, mercenaries, soldiers, troops, warriors</li>
219     *     <li>guard`noun` : defender, guard, guardian, knight, paladin, protector, sentinel, shield, templar, warden, watchman</li>
220     *     <li>guard`nouns` : defenders, guardians, guards, knights, paladins, protectors, sentinels, shields, templars, wardens, watchmen</li>
221     *     <li>hunter`noun` : hunter, poacher, stalker, tracker, trapper, warden</li>
222     *     <li>explorer`noun` : explorer, nomad, pathfinder, questant, seeker, wanderer</li>
223     *     <li>hunter`nouns` : hunters, poachers, stalkers, trackers, trappers, wardens</li>
224     *     <li>explorer`nouns` : explorers, nomads, pathfinders, questants, seekers, wanderers</li>
225     *     <li>rage`noun` : anger, frenzy, fury, rage, vengeance, wrath</li>
226     *     <li>ominous`adj` : baleful, fateful, foreboding, ominous, portentous</li>
227     *     <li>many`adj` : countless, infinite, manifold, many, myriad, thousandfold, unlimited</li>
228     *     <li>impossible`adj` : abominable, forbidden, impossible, incomprehensible, indescribable, ineffable, unearthly, unspeakable</li>
229     *     <li>gaze`noun` : eye, gaze, observation, purveyance, stare, watch</li>
230     *     <li>pain`noun` : agony, excruciation, misery, pain, torture</li>
231     *     <li>god`noun` : deity, father, god, king, lord, lordship, ruler</li>
232     *     <li>goddess`noun` : deity, goddess, lady, ladyship, mother, queen, ruler</li>
233     *     <li>hero`noun` : champion, crusader, hero, knight, savior</li>
234     *     <li>heroes`nouns` : champions, crusaders, heroes, knights, saviors</li>
235     *     <li>heroine`noun` : champion, crusader, heroine, knight, maiden, savior</li>
236     *     <li>heroines`nouns` : champions, crusaders, heroines, knights, maidens, saviors</li>
237     *     <li>popular`adj` : adored, beloved, revered, worshipped</li>
238     *     <li>unpopular`adj` : despised, hated, loathed, reviled</li>
239     *     <li>glyph`noun` : glyph, mark, seal, sigil, sign, symbol</li>
240     *     <li>glyph`nouns` : glyphs, marks, seals, sigils, signs, symbols</li>
241     *     <li>power`noun` : authority, dominance, force, potency, power, strength</li>
242     *     <li>power`adj` : authoritative, dominant, forceful, potent, powerful, strong</li>
243     * </ul>
244     * There are also terms, which typically produce multiple words procedurally and may use {@link #defaultLanguage}.
245     * See {@link #makePlantName()}, {@link #makeFruitName()}, {@link #makeNutName()}, {@link #makeFlowerName()}, and
246     * {@link #makePotionDescription()} for more info and examples.
247     * <li>
248     *     <li>plant`term` : @'s color`adj`     leaf`noun`, @'s color`adj` flower`noun`, @'s color`adj` tree`noun`, @'s flower`noun`, @'s ground`noun`  leaf`noun`, @'s sensory`adj`-leaf`noun`, @'s shape`adj` flower`noun`, @'s tree`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun` of @, color`adj` fruit`noun` tree`noun`, color`adj` nut`noun` tree`noun`, color`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, flavor`adj` fruit`noun` tree`noun`, flavor`adj` nut`noun` tree`noun`, flavor`noun` leaf`noun` tree`noun`, flower`noun` of @, ground`noun`  flower`noun`, ground`noun`      leaf`noun`, ground`noun`        leaf`noun` of @, leaf`noun` of @, sensory`adj` flower`noun` of @, sensory`adj` flower`noun`-flower`noun`, sensory`adj` tree`noun` of @, sensory`adj` tree`noun`-tree`noun`, sensory`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, sensory`adj`-leaf`noun` tree`noun`, shape`adj` flower`noun`, shape`adj`-fruit`noun` tree`noun`, shape`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, shape`adj`-leaf`noun` tree`noun`</li>
249     *     <li>fruit`term` : @'s color`adj` fruit`noun`, @'s flavor`adj` fruit`noun`, @'s fruit`noun`, color`adj` fruit`noun`-fruit`noun`, flavor`adj` fruit`noun`-fruit`noun`, fruit`noun` of @</li>
250     *     <li>nut`term` : @'s color`adj` nut`noun`, @'s flavor`adj` nut`noun`, @'s nut`noun`, color`adj` nut`noun`, color`adj` nut`noun` of @, flavor`adj` nut`noun`, nut`noun` of @, sensory`adj` nut`noun`</li>
251     *     <li>flower`term` : @'s color`adj` flower`noun`, @'s flower`noun`, @'s shape`adj` flower`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun` of @, color`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, flower`noun` of @, ground`noun`    flower`noun`, sensory`adj` flower`noun` of @, sensory`adj` flower`noun`-flower`noun`, sensory`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, shape`adj` flower`noun`, shape`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`</li>
252     *     <li>potion`term` : a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` containing a few drops of a color`adj` liquid`noun`, a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` filled with a color`adj` liquid`noun`, a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` filled with a liquid`adj` color`adj` liquid`noun`, a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` half-filled with a liquid`adj` color`adj` liquid`noun`, a calabash`adj` filled with a color`adj` liquid`noun`</li>
253     * </ul>
254     * Capitalizing the first letter in the keyword where it appears in text you call process() on will capitalize the
255     * first letter of the produced fake word. Capitalizing the second letter will capitalize the whole produced fake
256     * word. This applies only per-instance of each keyword; it won't change the internally-stored list of words.
257     * @return this for chaining
258     */
259    public Thesaurus addKnownCategories()
260    {
261        for(Map.Entry<String, ArrayList<String>> kv : categories.entrySet())
262        {
263            addCategory(kv.getKey(), kv.getValue());
264        }
265        plantTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(plantTerms, rng, true);
266        fruitTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(fruitTerms, rng, true);
267        nutTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(nutTerms, rng, true);
268        flowerTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(flowerTerms, rng, true);
269        potionTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(potionTerms, rng, true);
270        mappings.put("plant`term`", plantTermShuffler);
271        mappings.put("fruit`term`", fruitTermShuffler);
272        mappings.put("nut`term`", nutTermShuffler);
273        mappings.put("flower`term`", flowerTermShuffler);
274        mappings.put("potion`term`", potionTermShuffler);
275        return this;
276    }
277
278    /**
279     * Adds a large list of words pre-generated by FakeLanguageGen and hand-picked for fitness, and makes them
280     * accessible with a keyword based on the language. The keywords this currently knows:
281     * <br>
282     * "lovecraft`pre`", "english`pre`", "greek_romanized`pre`",
283     * "greek_authentic`pre`", "french`pre`", "russian_romanized`pre`",
284     * "russian_authentic`pre`", "japanese_romanized`pre`", "swahili`pre`",
285     * "somali`pre`", "hindi_romanized`pre`", "arabic_romanized`pre`",
286     * "inuktitut`pre`", "norse`pre`", "nahuatl`pre`", "mongolian`pre`",
287     * "fantasy`pre`", "fancy_fantasy`pre`", "goblin`pre`", "elf`pre`",
288     * "demonic`pre`", "infernal`pre`", "simplish`pre`", "alien_a`pre`",
289     * "korean_romanized`pre`", "alien_e`pre`", "alien_i`pre`", "alien_o`pre`",
290     * "alien_u`pre`", "dragon`pre`", "kobold`pre`", "insect`pre`", "maori`pre`",
291     * "spanish`pre`", "deep_speech`pre`", "norse_simplified`pre`",
292     * "hletkip`pre`", "ancient_egyptian`pre`", "crow`pre`", "imp`pre`",
293     * "malay`pre`", "celestial`pre`", "chinese_romanized`pre`",
294     * "cherokee_romanized`pre`", "vietnamese`pre`"
295     * <br>
296     * These correspond to similarly-named fields in {@link FakeLanguageGen}, just without {@code `pre`}; for instance
297     * {@code "cherokee_romanized`pre`"} corresponds to {@link FakeLanguageGen#CHEROKEE_ROMANIZED}. You can use these
298     * same keywords with {@code `gen`} instead of {@code `pre`} to generate at runtime based on the current RNG state,
299     * instead of using one of several pre-generated words, and doing that does not require addFakeWords() to be used.
300     * <br>
301     * Capitalizing the first letter in the keyword where it appears in text you call process() on will capitalize the
302     * first letter of the produced fake word, which is often desirable for things like place names. Capitalizing the
303     * second letter will capitalize the whole produced fake word. This applies only per-instance of each keyword; it
304     * won't change the internally-stored list of words.
305     * @return this for chaining
306     */
307    public Thesaurus addFakeWords()
308    {
309        //long state = rng.getState();
310        for(Map.Entry<CharSequence, FakeLanguageGen> kv : languages.entrySet())
311        {
312            ArrayList<String> words = new ArrayList<>(16);
313            for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++) {
314                words.add(kv.getValue().word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)));
315            }
316            addCategory(StringKit.replace(kv.getKey(), "`gen", "`pre"), words);
317        }
318        //rng.setState(state);
319        return this;
320    }
321
322    private StringBuilder modify(CharSequence text)
323    {
324        Matcher m;
325        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(text);
326        Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer tb, working = Replacer.wrap(sb);
327        StringBuilder tmp;
328        boolean found;
329        FakeLanguageGen.Alteration alt;
330        for (int a = 0; a < alterations.size(); a++) {
331            alt = alterations.get(a);
332            tmp = working.sb;
333            tb = Replacer.wrap(new StringBuilder(tmp.length()));
334            m = alt.replacer.getPattern().matcher(tmp);
335
336            found = false;
337            while (true) {
338                if (rng.nextDouble() < alt.chance) {
339                    if (!Replacer.replaceStep(m, alt.replacer.getSubstitution(), tb))
340                        break;
341                    found = true;
342                } else {
343                    if (!m.find())
344                        break;
345                    found = true;
346                    m.getGroup(MatchResult.PREFIX, tb);
347                    m.getGroup(MatchResult.MATCH, tb);
348                    m.setTarget(m, MatchResult.SUFFIX);
349                }
350            }
351            if (found) {
352                m.getGroup(MatchResult.TARGET, tb);
353                working = tb;
354            }
355        }
356        return working.sb;
357
358    }
359    /**
360     * Given a String, StringBuilder, or other CharSequence that should contain words this knows synonyms for, this
361     * replaces each occurrence of such a known word with one of its synonyms, leaving unknown words untouched. Words
362     * that were learned together as synonyms with addSynonyms() will be replaced in such a way that an individual
363     * replacement word should not occur too close to a previous occurrence of the same word; that is, replacing the
364     * text "You fiend! You demon! You despoiler of creation; devil made flesh!", where "fiend", "demon", and "devil"
365     * are all synonyms, would never produce a string that contained "fiend" as the replacement for all three of those.
366     * @param text a CharSequence, such as a String, that contains words in the source language
367     * @return a String of the translated text.
368     */
369    public String process(CharSequence text)
370    {
371//        Replacer rep = wordMatch.replacer(new SynonymSubstitution());
372        //String t = rep.replace(text);
373        Matcher m = wordMatch.matcher(text);
374        Substitution substitution = new SynonymSubstitution();
375        Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer dest = Replacer.wrap(new StringBuilder(text.length()));
376        while (m.find()) {
377            if (m.start() > 0) m.getGroup(MatchResult.PREFIX, dest);
378            substitution.appendSubstitution(m, dest);
379            m.setTarget(m, MatchResult.SUFFIX);
380        }
381        m.getGroup(MatchResult.TARGET, dest);
382
383        m.setTarget(dest.sb);
384        dest.sb.setLength(0);
385        while (m.find()) {
386            if (m.start() > 0) m.getGroup(MatchResult.PREFIX, dest);
387            substitution.appendSubstitution(m, dest);
388            m.setTarget(m, MatchResult.SUFFIX);
389        }
390        m.getGroup(MatchResult.TARGET, dest);
391
392        if(alterations.isEmpty())
393            return StringKit.replace(StringKit.correctABeforeVowel(dest.sb), "\t", "");
394        else
395            return StringKit.replace(modify(StringKit.correctABeforeVowel(dest.sb)), "\t", "");
396    }
397
398    public String lookup(String word)
399    {
400        if(word.isEmpty())
401            return word;
402        if("@".equals(word))
403        {
404            return defaultLanguage.word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4));
405        }
406        String word2 = word.toLowerCase();
407        if(mappings.containsKey(word2))
408        {
409            String nx = mappings.get(word2).next();
410            if(nx.isEmpty())
411                return nx;
412            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
413                return nx.toUpperCase();
414            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
415            {
416                return Character.toUpperCase(nx.charAt(0)) + nx.substring(1);
417            }
418            return nx;
419        }
420        else if(languages.containsKey(word2))
421        {
422            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
423                return languages.get(word2).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)).toUpperCase();
424            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
425            {
426                return languages.get(word2).word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4));
427            }
428            return languages.get(word2).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4));
429        }
430        return word;
431    }
432
433    private class SynonymSubstitution implements Substitution
434    {
435        private final StringBuilder temp = new StringBuilder(64);
436        @Override
437        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
438            //dest.append(lookup(match.group(0)));
439            temp.setLength(0);
440            match.getGroup(0, temp);
441            writeLookup(dest, temp);
442        }
443    }
444
445    private void writeLookup(TextBuffer dest, StringBuilder word) {
446        if(word == null || word.length() <= 0)
447            return;
448        if(word.charAt(0) == '@' && word.length() == 1)
449        {
450            dest.append(defaultLanguage.word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4)));
451            return;
452        }
453        else if(mappings.containsKey(word))
454        {
455            String nx = mappings.get(word).next();
456            if(nx.isEmpty())
457                return;
458            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
459            {
460                dest.append(nx.toUpperCase());
461                return;
462            }
463            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
464            {
465                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(nx.charAt(0)));
466                dest.append(nx.substring(1));
467                return;
468            }
469            dest.append(nx);
470            return;
471        }
472        else if(languages.containsKey(word))
473        {
474            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
475            {
476                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)).toUpperCase());
477            }
478            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
479            {
480                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4)));
481            }
482            else
483            {
484                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)));
485            }
486            return;
487        }
488        else if(numbers.containsKey(word))
489        {
490            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
491            {
492                dest.append(numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word)).toUpperCase());
493            }
494            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
495            {
496                String w = numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word));
497                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(w.charAt(0)));
498                dest.append(w.substring(1));
499            }
500            else
501            {
502                dest.append(numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word)));
503            }
504            return;
505        }
506        else if(numberAdjectives.containsKey(word))
507        {
508            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
509            {
510                dest.append(numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word)).toUpperCase());
511            }
512            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
513            {
514                String w = numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word));
515                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(w.charAt(0)));
516                dest.append(w.substring(1));
517            }
518            else
519            {
520                dest.append(numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word)));
521            }
522            return;
523        }
524        if(dest instanceof Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer)
525        {
526            ((Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer)dest).sb.append(word);
527        }
528        else
529            dest.append(word.toString());
530
531    }
532
533    private class RandomLanguageSubstitution implements Substitution
534    {
535        @Override
536        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
537            FakeLanguageGen lang = FakeLanguageGen.randomLanguage(rng.nextLong());
538            randomLanguages.add(lang);
539            if(match.isCaptured(1))
540            {
541                lang = FakeLanguageGen.randomLanguage(rng.nextLong());
542                randomLanguages.add(lang);
543                do {
544                    latestGenerated = randomLanguages.get(0).word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)))
545                            + "-" + randomLanguages.get(1).word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
546                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 5 || latestGenerated.length() >= 17);
547                dest.append(latestGenerated);
548            }
549            else
550            {
551                do{
552                    latestGenerated = lang.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
553                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 2 || latestGenerated.length() >= 11);
554                dest.append(latestGenerated);
555            }
556        }
557    }
558
559    private class KnownLanguageSubstitution implements Substitution
560    {
561        public FakeLanguageGen language;
562        public KnownLanguageSubstitution(FakeLanguageGen lang)
563        {
564            language = lang;
565        }
566        @Override
567        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
568            if (match.isCaptured(1)) {
569                do
570                {
571                    latestGenerated = language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5))) +
572                            "-" + language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
573                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 5 || latestGenerated.length() >= 17);
574                dest.append(latestGenerated);
575            } else
576            {
577                do{
578                    latestGenerated = language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
579                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 2 || latestGenerated.length() >= 11);
580                dest.append(latestGenerated);
581            }
582        }
583    }
584
585    /**
586     * Generates a random possible name for a nation, such as "Iond-Gouccief Alliance" or "The Last Drayo Commonwealth".
587     * May use accented characters, as in
588     * "Thdsh-Hyttilb Hegemony" or "The Glorious Ch Empire"; if you want to strip these out and replace accented
589     * chars with their un-accented counterparts, you can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
590     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
591     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making nation names, by
592     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
593     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the nation name, like "Drayo" in
594     * "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". If more than one language was used in the nation name, as in "Thdsh-Hyttilb
595     * Hegemony", you will have two languages in randomLanguages, so here "Thdsh" would be generated by the first
596     * language, and "Hyttilb" by the second language. Calling this method replaces the current contents of
597     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can. This also assigns the
598     * {@link #latestGenerated} field to contain the part of the nation name without any larger titles; in the case of
599     * "The Glorious Ch Empire", the latestGenerated field would be assigned "Ch" at the same time the longer name
600     * would be returned. This field will be reassigned if this method is called again.
601     *
602     * @return a random name for a nation or a loose equivalent to a nation, as a String
603     */
604    public String makeNationName()
605    {
606        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("empire`noun`"))
607        {
608            addKnownCategories();
609        }
610        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
611        int frustration = 0;
612        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
613            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
614        randomLanguages.clear();
615        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
616        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
617        return replacer.replace(working);
618    }
619    /**
620     * Generates a random possible name for a nation, such as "Iond-Gouccief Alliance" or "The Last Drayo Commonwealth",
621     * with the FakeLanguageGen already available instead of randomly created. May use accented characters, as in
622     * "Thdsh Hegemony" or "The Glorious Ch Empire",
623     * if the given language can produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars
624     * with their un-accented counterparts, you can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
625     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed, or simply get an accent-less language by
626     * calling {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents()} on the FakeLanguageGen you would give this. This assigns the
627     * {@link #latestGenerated} field to contain the part of the nation name without any larger titles; in the case of
628     * "The Glorious Ch Empire", the latestGenerated field would be assigned "Ch" at the same time the longer name
629     * would be returned. This field will be reassigned if this method is called again.
630     * <br>
631     * Some nation names use a hyphenated pairing of what would normally be names in two different languages; if one of
632     * those names is produced by this it will produce two names in the same linguistic style. The randomLanguages field
633     * is not populated by this method; it is assumed that since you are passing this a FakeLanguageGen, you already
634     * have the one you want to use anyway.
635     *
636     * @param language a FakeLanguageGen that will be used to construct any non-English names
637     * @return a random name for a nation or a loose equivalent to a nation, as a String
638     */
639    public String makeNationName(FakeLanguageGen language)
640    {
641        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("empire`noun`"))
642        {
643            addKnownCategories();
644        }
645        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
646        int frustration = 0;
647        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
648            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
649        randomLanguages.clear();
650        KnownLanguageSubstitution sub = new KnownLanguageSubstitution(language);
651        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
652        return replacer.replace(working);
653    }
654
655    /**
656     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "Ikesheha's maple" or "sugarleaf birch".
657     * May use accented characters, as in "Ema's greenwood", if the given language can
658     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
659     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which returns a CharSequence that can be converted
660     * to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
661     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making names, by
662     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
663     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the person or place name, like
664     * "Drayo" in "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". Calling this method replaces the current contents of
665     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can.
666     *
667     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
668     */
669    public String makePlantName()
670    {
671        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("tree`noun`"))
672        {
673            addKnownCategories();
674        }
675        if(plantTermShuffler == null)
676        {
677            plantTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(plantTerms, rng, true);
678        }
679        String working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
680        int frustration = 0;
681        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
682            working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
683        randomLanguages.clear();
684        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
685        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
686        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
687    }
688    /**
689     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "Ikesheha's maple" or "sugarleaf birch",
690     * with the FakeLanguageGen already available instead of randomly created. May use accented characters, as in
691     * "Ema's greenwood", if the given language can
692     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
693     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
694     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed, or simply get an accent-less language by
695     * calling {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents()} on the FakeLanguageGen you would give this.
696     *
697     * @param language a FakeLanguageGen that will be used to construct any non-English names
698     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
699     */
700    public String makePlantName(FakeLanguageGen language)
701    {
702        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("tree`noun`"))
703        {
704            addKnownCategories();
705        }
706        if(plantTermShuffler == null)
707        {
708            plantTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(plantTerms, rng, true);
709        }
710        String working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
711        int frustration = 0;
712        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
713            working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
714        randomLanguages.clear();
715        KnownLanguageSubstitution sub = new KnownLanguageSubstitution(language);
716        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
717        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
718    }

728     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the person or place name, like

818    /**
819     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "nut of Gikoim" or "Pelyt's cashew",
820     * with the FakeLanguageGen already available instead of randomly created.
821     * May use accented characters, as in "Ema's greenwood", if the given language can
822     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
823     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
824     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed, or simply get an accent-less language by
825     * calling {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents()} on the FakeLanguageGen you would give this.
826     *
827     * @param language a FakeLanguageGen that will be used to construct any non-English names
828     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
829     */
830    public String makeNutName(FakeLanguageGen language)
831    {
832        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("nut`noun`"))
833        {
834            addKnownCategories();
835        }
836        if(nutTermShuffler == null)
837        {
838            nutTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(nutTerms, rng, true);
839        }
840        String working = process(nutTermShuffler.next());
841        int frustration = 0;
842        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
843            working = process(nutTermShuffler.next());
844        randomLanguages.clear();
845        KnownLanguageSubstitution sub = new KnownLanguageSubstitution(language);
846        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
847        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
848    }
849
850    /**
851     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "tulip of Jirui" or "Komert's thorny lilac".
852     * May use accented characters, as in "Ema's greenwood", if the given language can
853     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
854     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which returns a CharSequence that can be converted
855     * to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
856     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making names, by
857     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
858     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the person or place name, like
859     * "Drayo" in "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". Calling this method replaces the current contents of
860     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can.
861     *
862     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
863     */
864    public String makeFlowerName()
865    {
866        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("flower`noun`"))
867        {
868            addKnownCategories();
869        }
870        if(flowerTermShuffler == null)
871        {
872            flowerTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(flowerTerms, rng, true);
873        }
874        String working = process(flowerTermShuffler.next());
875        int frustration = 0;
876        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
877            working = process(flowerTermShuffler.next());
878        randomLanguages.clear();
879        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
880        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
881        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
882    }
883    /**
884     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "tulip of Jirui" or "Komert's thorny lilac",
885     * with the FakeLanguageGen already available instead of randomly created. May use accented characters, as in
886     * "Ema's greenwood", if the given language can
887     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
888     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
889     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed, or simply get an accent-less language by
890     * calling {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents()} on the FakeLanguageGen you would give this.
891     *
892     * @param language a FakeLanguageGen that will be used to construct any non-English names
893     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
894     */
895    public String makeFlowerName(FakeLanguageGen language)
896    {
897        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("flower`noun`"))
898        {
899            addKnownCategories();
900        }
901        if(flowerTermShuffler == null)
902        {
903            flowerTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(flowerTerms, rng, true);
904        }
905        String working = process(flowerTermShuffler.next());
906        int frustration = 0;
907        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
908            working = process(flowerTermShuffler.next());
909        randomLanguages.clear();
910        KnownLanguageSubstitution sub = new KnownLanguageSubstitution(language);
911        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
912        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
913    }

915    /**
916     * Generates a random possible description for a potion in a container, such as "a smoky glass flask containing a
917     * few drops of an orange tonic", "a milk carton filled with a red fluid", "a shining silver bottle filled with an
918     * effervescent violet potion", or "a wineskin filled with a black serum".
919     *
920     * @return a random description for a potion or other liquid in a container
921     */
922    public String makePotionDescription()
923    {
924        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("liquid`noun`"))
925        {
926            addKnownCategories();
927        }
928        if(potionTermShuffler == null)
929        {
930            potionTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(potionTerms, rng, true);
931        }
932        String working = process(potionTermShuffler.next());
933        int frustration = 0;
934        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
935            working = process(potionTermShuffler.next());
936        return StringKit.correctABeforeVowel(working);
937    }
938
939    /**
940     * Gets an English word for a given number, if this knows it. These words are known from 0 ("zero") to 20
941     * ("twenty"), as well as some higher numbers. If a word isn't known for a number, this returns the number as a
942     * String, such as "537" or "-1".
943     * @param number the number to get a word for
944     * @return the word associated with a number as a String, or if none is known, {@code String.valueOf(number)}.
945     */
946    public static String numberWord(final int number)
947    {
948        switch (number){
949            case 0: return "zero";
950            case 1: return "one";
951            case 2: return "two";
952            case 3: return "three";
953            case 4: return "four";
954            case 5: return "five";
955            case 6: return "six";
956            case 7: return "seven";
957            case 8: return "eight";
958            case 9: return "nine";
959            case 10: return "ten";
960            case 11: return "eleven";
961            case 12: return "twelve";
962            case 13: return "thirteen";
963            case 14: return "fourteen";
964            case 15: return "fifteen";
965            case 16: return "sixteen";
966            case 17: return "seventeen";
967            case 18: return "eighteen";
968            case 19: return "nineteen";
969            case 20: return "twenty";
970            case 30: return "thirty";
971            case 40: return "fourty";
972            case 50: return "fifty";
973            case 60: return "sixty";
974            case 70: return "seventy";
975            case 80: return "eighty";
976            case 90: return "ninety";
977            case 100: return "hundred";
978            case 1000: return "thousand";
979            case 1000000: return "million";
980            case 1000000000: return "billion";
981            default: return String.valueOf(number);
982        }
983    }
984
985    /**
986     * Gets an English word that describes a numbered position in some sequence, if this knows it (such as "second" or
987     * "eleventh"). These words are known from 1 ("first") to 20 ("twentieth"), as well as some higher numbers. If a
988     * word isn't known for a number, this appends a suffix based on the last base-10 digit to the number, as with "0th"
989     * or "42nd".
990     * @param number the number to get a position adjective for
991     * @return the word associated with a number as a String, or if none is known, {@code String.valueOf(number)} followed by a two-char suffix from the last digit.
992     */
993    public static String numberAdjective(final int number)
994    {
995        switch (number){
996            case 1: return "first";
997            case 2: return "second";
998            case 3: return "third";
999            case 4: return "fourth";
1000            case 5: return "fifth";
1001            case 6: return "sixth";
1002            case 7: return "seventh";
1003            case 8: return "eighth";
1004            case 9: return "ninth";
1005            case 10: return "tenth";
1006            case 11: return "eleventh";
1007            case 12: return "twelfth";
1008            case 13: return "thirteenth";
1009            case 14: return "fourteenth";
1010            case 15: return "fifteenth";
1011            case 16: return "sixteenth";
1012            case 17: return "seventeenth";
1013            case 18: return "eighteenth";
1014            case 19: return "nineteenth";
1015            case 20: return "twentieth";
1016            case 30: return "thirtieth";
1017            case 40: return "fourtieth";
1018            case 50: return "fiftieth";
1019            case 60: return "sixtieth";
1020            case 70: return "seventieth";
1021            case 80: return "eightieth";
1022            case 90: return "ninetieth";
1023            case 100: return "hundredth";
1024            case 1000: return "thousandth";
1025            case 1000000: return "millionth";
1026            case 1000000000: return "billionth";
1027            default: 
1028            {
1029                switch (number % 10){
1030                    case 1: return number + "st";
1031                    case 2: return number + "nd";
1032                    case 3: return number + "rd";
1033                    default:return number + "th";
1034                }
1035            }
1036        }
1037    }
1038
1039    /**
1040     * Gets an English word for a number, if this knows it, where the number is chosen randomly between lowest and
1041     * highest, both inclusive. These words are known from 0 ("zero") to 20 ("twenty"), as well as some higher numbers.
1042     * If a word isn't known for a number, this returns the number as a String, such as "537" or "-1".
1043     * @param lowest the lower bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1044     * @param highest the upper bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1045     * @return a String word for a number in the given range, such as "six" or "eleven", if it is known
1046     */
1047    public String numberWordInRange(int lowest, int highest)
1048    {
1049        return numberWord(rng.nextSignedInt(highest + 1 - lowest) + lowest);
1050    }
1051    /**
1052     * Gets an English word that describes a numbered position in some sequence, if this knows it (such as "second" or
1053     * "eleventh"), where the number is chosen randomly between lowest and highest, both inclusive. These words are
1054     * known from 1 ("first") to 20 ("twentieth"), as well as some output for other numbers (such as "42nd" or "23rd").
1055     * @param lowest the lower bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1056     * @param highest the upper bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1057     * @return a String word for a number in the given range, such as "third" or "twelfth", if it is known
1058     */
1059    public String numberAdjectiveInRange(int lowest, int highest)
1060    {
1061        return numberAdjective(rng.nextSignedInt(highest + 1 - lowest) + lowest);
1062    }

1386    public static final OrderedMap<String, ArrayList<String>>
1387            adjective = new OrderedMap<>(categories),
1388            noun = new OrderedMap<>(categories),
1389            nouns = new OrderedMap<>(categories);
1390    public static final OrderedMap<CharSequence, FakeLanguageGen> languages = new OrderedMap<CharSequence, FakeLanguageGen>(
1391            FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
1392    static {
1393        for (int i = 0; i < FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length; i++) {
1394            languages.put(FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames[i].replace(' ', '_').toLowerCase() + "`gen`", FakeLanguageGen.registered[i]);
1395        }
1396    }

1448    /**
1449     * Thesaurus preset that changes all text to sound like this speaker: "Desaurus preset dat changez all text to sound
1450     * like dis speakah." You may be familiar with a certain sci-fi game that has orks who sound like this.
1451     */
1452    public static Thesaurus ORK = new Thesaurus("WAAAAAGH!");
1453    static {
1454        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("\\bth", "d"));
1455        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("th", "dd"));
1456        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("er\\b", "ah"));
1457        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("es\\b", "ez"));
1458        ORK.addReplacement("the", "da")
1459                .addReplacement("their", "deyr")
1460                .addReplacement("yes", "ya")
1461                .addReplacement("your", "youse")
1462                .addReplacement("yours", "youses")
1463                .addReplacement("going", "gon'")
1464                .addReplacement("and", "an'")
1465                .addReplacement("to", "*snort*")
1466                .addReplacement("rhythm", "riddim")
1467                .addReplacement("get", "git")
1468                .addReplacement("good", "gud");
1469        
1470        // not related to ORK; this filters out synonyms that aren't in the appropriate list
1471        Iterator<String> it = adjective.keySet().iterator();
1472        while (it.hasNext()){
1473            if(!it.next().contains("`adj`"))
1474                it.remove();
1475        }
1476        it = noun.keySet().iterator();
1477        while (it.hasNext()){
1478            if(!it.next().contains("`noun`"))
1479                it.remove();
1480        }
1481        it = nouns.keySet().iterator();
1482        while (it.hasNext()){
1483            if(!it.next().contains("`nouns`"))
1484                it.remove();
1485        }
1486
1487
1488    }
